instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> switching on and off every 0.5 sek or so. Clock chip is ok getting the 32Khz and the 25Mhz. What should I look for more ? No signs if water damage on the board. Anyone had this problem before?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: either bad <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, bad SMC, or bad <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>. Even though there is a resistor inbetween <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> if <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is bad it can drag that down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Ok, found that SMC was bad, after changing that had the computer working for 5min then <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> fried the CPU. :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: On another note had the same problem on an air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>(<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> equivalent on 3115 ect.) and it worked so not always the SMC. So its easy to desolder the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and see if the <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> signal becomes stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: same thing as what i said, <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> on an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> is <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> on a newer <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. it can pull down the signal from the smc. i always try the latter before the smc because it is easier to put back on :)
